articles.headline: Despite Mandate, I.R.S. Delayed Auditing Trump in Office, House Panel Finds
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump refused to disclose his taxes. A committee’s vote to release them ended an oversight battle Democratic lawmakers waged since 2019.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump refused to disclose his taxes. A committee’s vote to release them ended an oversight battle Democratic lawmakers waged since 2019.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service failed to audit former President Donald J. Trump during his first two years in office despite a program that makes the auditing of sitting presidents mandatory, a House committee revealed on Tuesday after an extraordinary vote to make public six years of his tax returns.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Emily Cochrane, Stephanie Lai and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Mark Zuckerberg Testifies About Meta’s Virtual Reality Ambitions
articles.snippet: Meta’s chief executive made a rare court appearance as the Federal Trade Commission tries to block his company’s purchase of the virtual reality start-up Within.
articles.abstract: Meta’s chief executive made a rare court appearance as the Federal Trade Commission tries to block his company’s purchase of the virtual reality start-up Within.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, was asked a series of questions in federal court on Tuesday about his aspirations for the immersive online world of the metaverse.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel and David McCabe

articles.headline: Elon Musk Says He Will Resign as Twitter C.E.O. When He Finds Successor
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk, who asked his Twitter followers on Sunday if he should step down as head of the service, will remain the company’s owner.
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk, who asked his Twitter followers on Sunday if he should step down as head of the service, will remain the company’s owner.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk said on Tuesday that he would resign as Twitter’s chief executive when he found “someone foolish enough to take the job,” two days after he had asked his 122 million Twitter followers whether he should step down as the leader of the social media site and a majority of respondents answered yes.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and Kate Conger

articles.headline: Zelensky Will Meet With Biden in Washington and Address Congress, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The visit will be the first time President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has left his country since Russia invaded in February.
articles.abstract: The visit will be the first time President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has left his country since Russia invaded in February.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine will meet with President Biden at the White House on Wednesday and later deliver a prime-time address to a joint session of Congress, a daring trip abroad intended to reaffirm American support for his country, White House officials announced late Tuesday night.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: A New Chat Bot Is a ‘Code Red’ for Google’s Search Business
articles.snippet: A new wave of chat bots like ChatGPT use artificial intelligence that could reinvent or even replace the traditional internet search engine.
articles.abstract: A new wave of chat bots like ChatGPT use artificial intelligence that could reinvent or even replace the traditional internet search engine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past three decades, a handful of products like Netscape’s web browser, Google’s search engine and Apple’s iPhone have truly upended the tech industry and made what came before them look like lumbering dinosaurs.
articles.byline: By Nico Grant and Cade Metz

articles.headline: How to Use ChatGPT and Still Be a Good Person
articles.snippet: It’s a turning point for artificial intelligence, and we need to take advantage of these tools without causing harm to ourselves or others.
articles.abstract: It’s a turning point for artificial intelligence, and we need to take advantage of these tools without causing harm to ourselves or others.
articles.lead_paragraph: The past few weeks have felt like a honeymoon phase for our relationship with tools powered by artificial intelligence.

articles.headline: At Berkeley Law, a Debate Over Zionism, Free Speech and Campus Ideals
articles.snippet: A student group, Law Students for Justice in Palestine, barred supporters of Zionism from speaking at its events. The outrage — and legal misunderstandings — grew from there.
articles.abstract: A student group, Law Students for Justice in Palestine, barred supporters of Zionism from speaking at its events. The outrage — and legal misunderstandings — grew from there.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the first day of the fall semester, Erwin Chemerinsky, the dean of the law school at the University of California, Berkeley, learned that a student group created a bylaw that banned supporters of Zionism from speaking at its events.

articles.headline: Electric Cars Are Taking Off, but When Will Battery Recycling Follow?
articles.snippet: Many companies and investors are eager to recycle batteries, but it could take a decade or more before enough used lithium-ion batteries become available.
articles.abstract: Many companies and investors are eager to recycle batteries, but it could take a decade or more before enough used lithium-ion batteries become available.
articles.lead_paragraph: Benjamin Reynaga used power tools to hack his way into a beat-up hybrid Honda Fit at an auto dismantling plant at the edge of the Mojave Desert until he reached the most important part of the car: its lithium-ion battery.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: How New I.R.S. Rules Could Affect Venmo, Etsy and Cash App Users
articles.snippet: Some users of digital wallets and e-commerce platforms must start reporting small transactions, sowing fears among small-business owners.
articles.abstract: Some users of digital wallets and e-commerce platforms must start reporting small transactions, sowing fears among small-business owners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This year, Dennis Turbeville, a woodworker in Washington, used the mobile payment service Venmo to sell his wares, collect payments on a rental property and split personal expenses with family and friends.
